author: @Frenchised
text: I love the motivation behind this video! 6 months ago I decided I wanted to be a Data Analyst. I cut out my distractions and set some goals. I took the Google Certificate, completed the capstone, built a portfolio, and 3 weeks ago I started applying to jobs. Its definitely tough juggling a full time job/family as well but I can‚Äôt wait to see where the grind gets me in the long run! Currently I spend 2h every day of the week job hunting/applying and every weekend working on projects to add to my portfolio. I keep telling myself all this hard work has to pay off, I can‚Äôt wait! Now if only I could find some time to take more Coursera courses haha.

author: @kae0_o644
text: Hard agree with physically removing distractions.  Part of what makes distractions so easy to fall prey to is the easy access to them.  If you have to put in more than minimal amount of effort (like looking up a password) to start the distraction, unless there's serious avoidance issues at play you likely won't do that activity. Completely removing options that let you avoid doing what you need to do is a game changer.

author: @harrietdrums
text: My ADHD went undiagnosed till last year at 27, and even now with treatment, procrastination is always going to be an issue for me. Something that sounds so simple like "just get rid of distractions" does not work for me, as I can be distracted by literally anything and everything. If any ADHDers are reading this, you CAN progress but it is a lot harder and you do need to find things that work with your brain - neurotypical advice like "get a planner" does not usually work for us.   Data analysis is actually great for ADHD brains as we are creative, problem solvers, we think outside the box, and are great at pattern recognition. Despite the misleading name we also have great attention to detail. I found your channel when I was looking into data as a career, I'm almost done with the Google DA Cert and I just landed my first job in data. I've only been taking this seriously for 5 months.   Alex this isn't to discount your advice or anything, but just reassurance for anyone else here with ADHD - we beat ourselves up a lot for procrastinating and not feeling good enough but it's a result of our disability, our brains are different and we have to work around that.

author: @agigcbo
text: Time & energy - those are my blockers. For me, it's creating extra time and energy in addition to my 50-hour/week full-time job. I realize some might argue that if it's a priority, you'll make the time for it. The only success I've had at attacking this issue is trying to spread studying and prep time out into 30-minute chunks since I can't afford an additional 2-3 hours per day. I'd have no balance if that were the case. Adding this type of activity in incremental chunks is the only way I can do this and not sacrifice too much family time.
